update.description:
Remove `Iface` and move its functionality to `Application`, which subclasses `QGuiApplication`.

This uses the fact that Qt enforces a single application per process, which is a singleton accessible from other classes. Also make better use of Qt's API to get windows and dialogs in the app.

This is a first pass. I also want to see how much of the `MainWindow` class I can merge with `Application`. There are functions I was putting there just because it was a `QObject`, while `Iface` wasn't.

This PR includes the test fixes from ~~pull request #127~~ (merged), but migrated to use the new class.
update.title: [gz11] Application

update.description:
Remove `Iface` and move its functionality to `Application`, which subclasses `QGuiApplication`.

This uses the fact that Qt enforces a single application per process, which is a singleton accessible from other classes. Also make better use of Qt's API to get windows and dialogs in the app.

This is a first pass. I also want to see how much of the `MainWindow` class I can merge with `Application`. There are functions I was putting there just because it was a `QObject`, while `Iface` wasn't.

update.title: [gz11] Application

content.raw:
It's not immediately clear to me if there's any advantage to adding the config to the constructor, because we'd have to deal with the empty string case.

When using ign-gui's command line, we load the default configuration (i.e. `~/.ignition/gui/default.config`) whenever the user runs `ign gui` without specific config or plugin.

For downstream projects, I think it's nice to support multiple paths so each project has the flexibility to implement what's most appropriate for them. They should be able to open an empty window, the default config (ign-gui's or their own), a combination of config and plugins and configure window and plugins before executing.

I propose we leave `LoadDefaultConfig` as public, and if an empty string is passed to `LoadConfig` it fails.
content.html:
It's not immediately clear to me if there's any advantage to adding the config to the constructor, because we'd have to deal with the empty string case.

When using ign-gui's command line, we load the default configuration (i.e. ~/.ignition/gui/default.config) whenever the user runs ign gui without specific config or plugin.

For downstream projects, I think it's nice to support multiple paths so each project has the flexibility to implement what's most appropriate for them. They should be able to open an empty window, the default config (ign-gui's or their own), a combination of config and plugins and configure window and plugins before executing.

I propose we leave LoadDefaultConfig as public, and if an empty string is passed to LoadConfig it fails.

content.raw:
That looks good. Do you want to add the configuration as an optional parameter to the constructor? 

    
    Application::Application(int &_argc, char **_argv, const WindowType _type, const std::string &_config="")
    

One question I have is when do we want to load the default config, and when should we not? For example, if a user wants just a mainwindow, should we load the default config? If if the user specifies plugins should the default config not be loaded?
content.html:
That looks good. Do you want to add the configuration as an optional parameter to the constructor? 

Application::Application(int &_argc, char **_argv, const WindowType _type, const std::string &_config="")

One question I have is when do we want to load the default config, and when should we not? For example, if a user wants just a mainwindow, should we load the default config? If if the user specifies plugins should the default config not be loaded?

Sorry

Maybe this could be a clearer API?

ignition::gui::Application app(_argc, _argv, kMainWindow);
app.LoadConfig(config);
app.LoadPlugin(plugin);
app.exec();
  • Prevents loading config/plugin before window initialization
  • Enforces window initialization
  • Downstream developers still have the flexibility to configure the app before exec

content.html: But if we do want to load the default config, then we pass an empty string to the second initialize, right? Maybe that can become a bit confusing?

content.raw: With this change a user would have to call `LoadConfig` or `LoadDefaultConfig`, correct?
content.html: With this change a user would have to call LoadConfig or LoadDefaultConfig, correct?

content.raw: How about changing the `if` statement in the third Initialize to not `LoadDefaultConfig` if `_config` is empty?
content.html: How about changing the if statement in the third Initialize to not LoadDefaultConfig if _config is empty?

Something like this:

diff -r d717a5f9b9e8 include/ignition/gui/Application.hh
--- a/include/ignition/gui/Application.hh       Tue Jun 26 18:47:54 2018 -0700
+++ b/include/ignition/gui/Application.hh       Wed Jun 27 13:50:29 2018 -0700
@@ -86,13 +86,10 @@
       public: bool Initialize(const WindowType _type,
                               const std::string &_config);

-      /// \brief Initialize the application window(s) with a given
-      /// configuration and plugins.
+      /// \brief Initialize the application window(s) with the given plugins.
       /// \param[in] _type Window type, such as main window or dialog.
-      /// \param[in] _config Path to config file.
       /// \param[in] _plugins Configuration for plugins
       public: bool Initialize(const WindowType _type,
-                              const std::string &_config,
                               const std::vector<PluginConfig> &_plugins);

       /// \brief Get the QML engine
diff -r d717a5f9b9e8 src/Application.cc
--- a/src/Application.cc        Tue Jun 26 18:47:54 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/Application.cc        Wed Jun 27 13:50:29 2018 -0700
@@ -391,7 +391,6 @@

 /////////////////////////////////////////////////
 bool Application::Initialize(const WindowType _type,
-                             const std::string &_config,
                              const std::vector<PluginConfig> &_plugins)
 {
   for (const auto plugin : _plugins)
@@ -400,11 +399,6 @@
       return false;
   }

-  if (_config.empty())
-    this->LoadDefaultConfig();
-  else
-    this->LoadConfig(_config);
-
   return this->Initialize(_type);
 }

diff -r d717a5f9b9e8 src/Application_TEST.cc
--- a/src/Application_TEST.cc   Tue Jun 26 18:47:54 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/Application_TEST.cc   Wed Jun 27 13:50:29 2018 -0700
@@ -323,7 +323,8 @@
     app.AddPluginPath(testBuildPath);

     // Initialize dialog
-    EXPECT_TRUE(app.Initialize(WindowType::kDialog, "", {{"TestPlugin"}}));
+    PluginConfig plugin{"TestPlugin"};
+    EXPECT_TRUE(app.Initialize(WindowType::kDialog, {plugin}));

     // Close dialog after some time
     auto closed = false;
@@ -357,8 +358,8 @@
     app.AddPluginPath(testBuildPath);

     // Initialize dialogs
-    EXPECT_TRUE(app.Initialize(WindowType::kDialog, "",
-          {{"TestPlugin"}, {"TestPlugin"}}));
+    std::vector<PluginConfig> plugins{{"TestPlugin"}, {"TestPlugin"}};
+    EXPECT_TRUE(app.Initialize(WindowType::kDialog, plugins));

     // Close dialogs after some time
     auto closed = false;
diff -r d717a5f9b9e8 src/Plugin_TEST.cc
--- a/src/Plugin_TEST.cc        Tue Jun 26 18:47:54 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/Plugin_TEST.cc        Wed Jun 27 13:50:29 2018 -0700
@@ -56,8 +56,8 @@
   pluginDoc.Parse(pluginStr);

   // Create main window
-  EXPECT_TRUE(app.Initialize(WindowType::kMainWindow, "",
-        {{"TestPlugin", pluginDoc.FirstChildElement("plugin")}}));
+  PluginConfig plugin{"TestPlugin", pluginDoc.FirstChildElement("plugin")};
+  EXPECT_TRUE(app.Initialize(WindowType::kMainWindow, {plugin}));

   auto win = app.findChild<MainWindow *>();
   ASSERT_NE(nullptr, win);
diff -r d717a5f9b9e8 src/ign.cc
--- a/src/ign.cc        Tue Jun 26 18:47:54 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/ign.cc        Wed Jun 27 13:50:29 2018 -0700
@@ -63,8 +63,8 @@
 {
   ignition::gui::Application app(g_argc, g_argv);

-  if (!app.Initialize(ignition::gui::WindowType::kDialog, "",
-      {{_filename}}))
+  ignition::gui::PluginConfig plugin{_filename};
+  if (!app.Initialize(ignition::gui::WindowType::kDialog, {plugin}))
   {
     return;
   }

content.raw: When we pass an empty string for the config, we load the default config. But in the case when we name specific plugins, we most likely don't want to load the default config as well. I'd propose we remove the config from the 3rd `Initialize` function, but I'm afraid that would make the usage less compact, because we wouldn't be able to use initializer lists for the plugins.
content.html: When we pass an empty string for the config, we load the default config. But in the case when we name specific plugins, we most likely don't want to load the default config as well. I'd propose we remove the config from the 3rd Initialize function, but I'm afraid that would make the usage less compact, because we wouldn't be able to use initializer lists for the plugins.

update.description:
Remove `Iface` and move its functionality to `Application`, which subclasses `QGuiApplication`.

This uses the fact that Qt enforces a single application per process, which is a singleton accessible from other classes. Also make better use of Qt's API to get windows and dialogs in the app.

This is a first pass. I also want to see how much of the `MainWindow` class I can merge with `Application`. There are functions I was putting there just because it was a `QObject`, while `Iface` wasn't.

This PR includes the test fixes from ~~pull request #127~~ (merged), but migrated to use the new class.
update.title: [gz11] Application

content.html:
I just realized this approach takes away a bit of flexibility from downstream projects. For example, there's a project doing the following:

  // Attempt to load window layout from default config file.
  // If it's not available, load it from configFile.
  if (!ignition::gui::loadDefaultConfig()) {
    // If config file parsed from args is not
    // a valid path, exit the application.
    if(!ignition::gui::loadConfig(configFile)) {
      return 1;
    }
  }

  // Create main window (i.e. InitializeMainWindow)
  ignition::gui::createMainWindow();

By making LoadDefaultConfig private, we prevent them from doing these kinds of checks.

I think we can support all these cases without much effort:

  • Load plugins/config after initializing window (needs to be supported anyway for the GUI)
  • Load plugins/config before initializing window (just to prevent errors in case user initializes afterwards)
  • Load plugins/config while initializing window (added by your branch)

This uses the fact that Qt enforces a single application per process, which is a singleton accessible from other classes. Also make better use of Qt's API to get windows and dialogs in the app.

update.title: [gz11] Application

content.raw:
A proposal to simplify the Application API is [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/branch/gz11_app_nate?dest=gz11_app#diff).

The goal I was trying to achieve is:

1. Reduce the number of entry points. Currently there is an Exec entry point and an Load/Init entry point.
2. Use a Create / Init / Exec series that is a bit more explicit. Currently, a user would have to run “LoadConfig” and “LoadPlugin” before running an “Init” function. The proposal combines the “Load” and “init” so that order does not matter to the user, and they have fewer function to call.

The proposal is still rough.
content.html:
A proposal to simplify the Application API is here.

The goal I was trying to achieve is:

  1. Reduce the number of entry points. Currently there is an Exec entry point and an Load/Init entry point.
  2. Use a Create / Init / Exec series that is a bit more explicit. Currently, a user would have to run “LoadConfig” and “LoadPlugin” before running an “Init” function. The proposal combines the “Load” and “init” so that order does not matter to the user, and they have fewer function to call.

The proposal is still rough.

content.raw:
I think the only problem people will face is figuring out what dependencies are required. Installing ign-gui from a debian will be fine since the dependencies should be built in. When compiling from source, it would be great if cmake could error out if a dependency is missing. This might be hard to do since these are run-time dependencies. 

You could turn this into an issue that we can address later.
content.html:
I think the only problem people will face is figuring out what dependencies are required. Installing ign-gui from a debian will be fine since the dependencies should be built in. When compiling from source, it would be great if cmake could error out if a dependency is missing. This might be hard to do since these are run-time dependencies.

You could turn this into an issue that we can address later.

content.raw: Thanks, I just realized all those were already listed on pipelines. Please let me know if you run into any other missing ones.
content.html: Thanks, I just realized all those were already listed on pipelines. Please let me know if you run into any other missing ones.

content.raw:
Thanks for this question, the API is indeed quite confusing. I improved it a bit on db71722, let me know what you think. Functions `AddPluginsToWindow` and `ApplyConfig` are still a bit fuzzy, but I'd like to revisit them once I refactor `MainWindow` if that's ok with you.

While refactoring, I also created an example to run multiple dialogs and realized that is not working properly, even though the tests pass. I added a TODO for later.
content.html:
Thanks for this question, the API is indeed quite confusing. I improved it a bit on db71722, let me know what you think. Functions AddPluginsToWindow and ApplyConfig are still a bit fuzzy, but I'd like to revisit them once I refactor MainWindow if that's ok with you.

While refactoring, I also created an example to run multiple dialogs and realized that is not working properly, even though the tests pass. I added a TODO for later.
